segments.en: Hello, everyone, and welcome to EnglishPod.
My name is Marco.
My name is Kathryn, and today we're talking about something that I think a lot of people experience, especially with certain things like peanuts and cats.
segments.cn: 我叫Kathryn，今天我们要谈论一些我认为很多人都会经历的事情，尤其是像花生和猫这样的东西。

segments.en: So what are we talking about?
That's right.
Today we are talking about allergies.
So that means that we have a problem with maybe cats.
segments.cn: 这意味着我们可能对猫有问题。

segments.en: They make us sick or with certain foods.
segments.cn: 它们让我们生病，或者对某些食物。

segments.en: Like a lot of people who are allergic to milk, actually.
segments.cn: 比如很多人对牛奶过敏。

segments.en: That's right.
So we're going to talk about a couple of these allergies and symptoms.
segments.cn: 所以我们将讨论几种过敏和症状。

segments.en: So why don't we have a listen to our dialogue and we'll be back in a bit.
segments.cn: 那我们来听听对话，稍后再回来。

segments.en: Oh, I feel terrible.
I keep sneezing and my eyes are all watery.
segments.cn: 我不停打喷嚏，眼睛都流泪了。

segments.en: What's wrong with me?
Wow, you're not dying, are you?
Looks like you have a cold.
You should take some medicine.
I don't think it's a cold.
I feel fine if I move a few feet away from my desk.
segments.cn: 如果我离开桌子几步，我感觉很好。

segments.en: Maybe we should put you into quarantine.
segments.cn: 也许我们应该把你隔离起来。

segments.en: Jokes aside, I think you might have an allergy.
segments.cn: 开玩笑的，我觉得你可能有过敏。

segments.en: An allergy?
I never thought about that.
I don't think I'm allergic to pollen, though, and I'm desensitized to bee stings after being stung so many times.
segments.cn: 不过我觉得我对花粉不敏感，而且被蜜蜂蜇了这么多次后我已经脱敏了。

segments.en: Hmm.
Ow!
Why did you Chuck that peanut at me?
segments.cn: 你为什么把那个花生扔给我？

segments.en: Just checking if you're allergic to peanuts.
segments.cn: 只是想看看你对花生过敏吗。

segments.en: I guess not.
Not funny.
I could have gone into anaphylactic shock.
segments.cn: 我可能会进入过敏性休克。

segments.en: Okay, my bad.
How about dust?
This office is full of it.
Yes, the whole office is dusty, yet I only feel affected near our desks.
segments.cn: 是的，整个办公室都很脏，但我只在我们的桌子附近感到受影响。

segments.en: You brought your cat into the office?
segments.cn: 你把你的猫带到办公室了吗？

segments.en: Yeah, it's Mr. Snuffle's birthday today.
segments.cn: 是的，今天是Mr. Snuffle的生日。

segments.en: I didn't want him to be alone on his special day.
segments.cn: 我不想让他在特别的日子里孤单。

segments.en: Ah, put it away!
I guess we found the problem.
You're allergic to cats.
Alright, so now let's take a look at vocab on Language Takeaway.
segments.cn: 好吧，现在让我们看看Language Takeaway的词汇。

segments.en: Alright, so Marco, we have a number of things that might happen if you're feeling like you're allergic to something.
segments.cn: 好吧，Marco，如果你感觉对某些东西过敏，可能会发生一些事情。

segments.en: The first one is, my eyes are all watery.
segments.cn: 第一个是，我的眼睛都流泪了。

segments.en: Okay, so your eyes get watery, and that means you start to have a lot of water, a lot of tears in your eyes.
segments.cn: 好吧，你的眼睛流泪了，这意味着你开始有很多水，很多泪水在眼睛里。

segments.en: That's right, but you're not sad, you're not crying, it's just that you have this reaction that you cannot control, and the water maybe comes down from your eyes.
segments.cn: 没错，但你并不伤心，也没有哭，只是你有这种无法控制的反应，水可能从你的眼睛流下来。

segments.en: Right, usually your eyes get wet and watery, itchy, red, so a lot of that.
segments.cn: 对，通常你的眼睛会湿润、流泪、发痒、发红，很多这样的情况。

segments.en: There's another thing too, this happens a lot, you feel like you can't stop sneezing.
segments.cn: 还有另一种情况，这种情况很常见，你感觉自己无法停止打喷嚏。

segments.en: To sneeze.
A sneeze is something you do when the air comes out of your nose.
segments.cn: 打喷嚏是指空气从你的鼻子里出来。

segments.en: Out of your nose, out of your mouth, out of everywhere.
segments.cn: 从你的鼻子、嘴巴，甚至是任何地方。

segments.en: Yeah, and you can't control it, and sometimes it's very, very strong.
segments.cn: 是的，你无法控制，有时非常强烈。

segments.en: You move your head, but it's something that you do when you're allergic to something like a cat or a flower, but also maybe when you smell something, some spice like hot pepper.
segments.cn: 你动动头，但这是你对像猫或花这样的东西过敏时会发生的事情，但也可能是当你闻到某种香料，比如辣椒时。

segments.en: Yeah, or when you're sick, when you have a cold.
segments.cn: 是的，或者当你生病时，感冒的时候。

segments.en: That's right.
And so his friend says that maybe they should put him into quarantine.
segments.cn: 他的朋友说也许他们应该把他隔离。

segments.en: Alright, now this is a joke.
If you have allergies, you don't have to go to quarantine, but quarantine is very serious.
segments.cn: 如果你有过敏，你不需要去隔离，但隔离是非常严肃的。

segments.en: It's a place where people go when they have a dangerous or very infectious disease, and quarantine means that no one else can come in and you cannot go out.
segments.cn: 这是人们在有危险或非常传染的疾病时去的地方，隔离意味着没有其他人可以进来，你也不能出去。

segments.en: Right, exactly.
So I think when they had the pig flu, the swine flu, many people were put into quarantine to make sure they didn't give it to someone else.
segments.cn: 所以我认为当他们有猪流感时，很多人被隔离以确保他们不会传染给其他人。

segments.en: That's right.
So usually in quarantine you have to wait until you can prove that you're not sick anymore, and then you get to leave.
segments.cn: 所以通常在隔离中，你必须等到你能证明自己不再生病，然后才能离开。

segments.en: That's right.
Alright, so they were talking about maybe the options of what he is allergic to.
segments.cn: 好吧，他们在讨论他可能对什么过敏的选项。

segments.en: He says, I don't think I'm allergic to pollen, so what is pollen and where does it come from?
segments.cn: 他说，我觉得我对花粉不敏感，那么花粉是什么，来自哪里？

segments.en: Alright, now pollen is actually a very common allergy, and pollen comes from flowers.
segments.cn: 好吧，花粉实际上是一种非常常见的过敏源，花粉来自花。

segments.en: It's kind of like a special dust or a special kind of thing that you see on flowers that gets blown away.
segments.cn: 它有点像一种特殊的灰尘或一种你在花上看到的特殊东西，会被吹走。

segments.en: So when it's springtime, many people suffer from allergies because there's a lot more pollen in the air.
segments.cn: 所以在春天，很多人因为空气中有更多的花粉而遭受过敏。

segments.en: So it's that little dust, usually sometimes yellow, that you can find on flowers.
segments.cn: 所以就是那种小灰尘，通常有时是黄色的，可以在花上找到。

segments.en: And this is actually what butterflies and bees look for.
segments.cn: 这实际上是蝴蝶和蜜蜂寻找的东西。

segments.en: That's right.
And then he talked about, well, he's not allergic to bees, and his friend threw a peanut at him, but he said it in a very strange way.
segments.cn: 然后他谈到，他对蜜蜂不过敏，他的朋友把一个花生扔给他，但他说得很奇怪。

segments.en: He said, why did you Chuck that peanut at me?
segments.cn: 他说，为什么你把那个花生扔给我？

segments.en: To Chuck.
Now this is a very spoken English way of saying something.
segments.cn: 这是一种非常口语化的英语表达。

segments.en: To Chuck means to throw.
So like, Marco, why did you Chuck that pillow at me?
segments.cn: 所以，Marco，你为什么把那个枕头扔给我？

segments.en: That was mean.
Alright, so to Chuck is to throw, but usually to throw something strongly.
segments.cn: 好吧，扔就是投掷，但通常是强烈地投掷某物。

segments.en: So, as you said, it's very spoken English.
segments.cn: 所以，正如你所说，这是一种非常口语化的英语。

segments.en: It's not really proper to actually write it or say it to someone in a formal occasion.
segments.cn: 在正式场合实际上不太适合写或对某人说。

segments.en: Yeah, that's right.
So you wouldn't say this in your English exam, but you could say this with your friends.
segments.cn: 所以你不会在英语考试中说这个，但你可以在朋友之间说。

segments.en: Okay, so to Chuck something.
So that's all the vocab we have for you.
segments.cn: 所以这就是我们为你准备的所有词汇。

segments.en: Why don't we go back and listen to the dialogue again.
Oh, I feel terrible.
I keep sneezing and my eyes are all watery.
segments.cn: 我不停打喷嚏，眼睛都流泪了。

segments.en: What's wrong with me?
Wow, you're not dying, are you?
Looks like you have a cold.
You should take some medicine.
I don't think it's a cold.
I feel fine if I move a few feet away from my desk.
segments.cn: 如果我离开桌子几步，我感觉很好。

segments.en: Maybe we should put you into quarantine.
segments.cn: 也许我们应该把你隔离。

segments.en: Jokes aside, I think you might have an allergy.
segments.cn: 开玩笑的，我觉得你可能有过敏。

segments.en: An allergy?
I never thought about that.
I don't think I'm allergic to pollen, though.
segments.cn: 我觉得我对花粉不敏感。

segments.en: And I'm desensitized to bee stings after being stung so many times.
segments.cn: 而且我在被蜜蜂蜇了这么多次后，对蜜蜂蜇的反应已经减弱了。

segments.en: Hmm... Ow!
Why did you Chuck that peanut at me?
segments.cn: 你为什么把那个花生扔给我？

segments.en: Just checking if you're allergic to peanuts.
segments.cn: 只是想检查一下你是否对花生过敏。

segments.en: I guess not.
Not funny.
I could have gone into anaphylactic shock.
segments.cn: 我可能会进入过敏性休克。

segments.en: Okay, my bad.
How about dust?
This office is full of it.
Yes, the whole office is dusty, yet I only feel affected near our desks.
segments.cn: 是的，整个办公室都很脏，但我只在我们的桌子附近感到受影响。

segments.en: You brought your cat into the office?
segments.cn: 你把你的猫带到办公室来了？

segments.en: Yeah, it's Mr. Snuffle's birthday today.
segments.cn: 是的，今天是斯纳夫尔先生的生日。

segments.en: I didn't want him to be alone on his special day.
segments.cn: 我不想让他在特别的日子里孤单。

segments.en: Ah, put it away!
I guess we found the problem.
You're allergic to cats.
Alright, we're back, so now it's time for Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 好吧，我们回来了，现在是流利度提升时间。

segments.en: Alright, now we heard a very difficult word later on in the dialogue.
segments.cn: 好吧，我们在对话中听到了一个非常困难的词。

segments.en: Jim said, Not funny.
I could have gone into anaphylactic shock.
segments.cn: 我可能会进入过敏性休克。

segments.en: Right.
Alright, so this phrase, to go into shock, is very important.
segments.cn: 好吧，这个短语“进入休克”非常重要。

segments.en: Go into shock.
Now, what does it mean to go into shock?
segments.cn: 现在，进入休克是什么意思？

segments.en: Well, shock is something, especially anaphylactic shock, which means that I think you stop breathing, because your body basically shuts down and your throat tightens so you can't breathe.
segments.cn: 嗯，休克，尤其是过敏性休克，意味着我想你会停止呼吸，因为你的身体基本上关闭了，喉咙收紧，所以你无法呼吸。

segments.en: But to go into shock means that your body will kind of stop doing its normal functions.
segments.cn: 但进入休克意味着你的身体会停止正常功能。

segments.en: For example, if you fall in very, very, very cold water, your body goes into shock.
segments.cn: 例如，如果你掉进非常非常冷的水里，你的身体会进入休克。

segments.en: Right.
And this is something that is a physical reaction.
You see it all the time in movies, I think, when a nurse or a doctor or someone yells, He's going into shock.
segments.cn: 我想你在电影中经常看到，当护士或医生或其他人喊：“他要进入休克了。”

segments.en: Right?
That's right, and they have to get the paddles and beep.
segments.cn: 没错，他们必须拿起电击器和仪器。

segments.en: Right, exactly.
So that's what it means when you go into shock.
segments.cn: 所以这就是进入休克的意思。

segments.en: But you use this verb.
You go into shock.
He's going into shock.
That's right, doctor.
He's gone into shock.
Uh -huh.
And, well, he said, Okay, I'm sorry.
segments.cn: 而且，他说，好吧，我很抱歉。

segments.en: My bad.
He said, My bad.
What is my bad?
Alright, my bad is another phrase that comes from spoken English, so be careful with how you use it.
segments.cn: 好吧，我错了是一个来自口语英语的短语，所以使用时要小心。

segments.en: This is something you can use with your friends.
segments.cn: 这是你可以和朋友使用的东西。

segments.en: My bad is a way of saying, My fault.
segments.cn: 我错了是一种说法，意思是“我的错”。

segments.en: Or, Excuse me.
My mistake.
My mistake.
So, if you do something wrong, and you say, Oh, I'm sorry.
segments.cn: 所以，如果你做错了什么，你可以说，哦，我很抱歉。

segments.en: That was my mistake.
You can just say, Oh, my bad.
segments.cn: 你可以直接说，哦，我错了。

segments.en: That's right.
Or, you know, Jerry, can we go outside for a second?
segments.cn: 或者，你知道，杰瑞，我们可以出去一下吗？

segments.en: I don't have to talk to you.
I mean, Marco.
Oh, my bad.
Right, exactly.
That means, you know, my fault.
I'm sorry.
I made a mistake.
So, but this is very colloquial, and I think it's very juvenile, right?
segments.cn: 所以，这非常口语化，我觉得这很幼稚，对吧？

segments.en: I think younger people use this, My bad.
segments.cn: 我觉得年轻人使用这个，我错了。

segments.en: My bad.
Yeah, it's younger.
Yeah.
That's a younger.
Alright.
And for our last phrase, when Jim was talking about maybe being allergic to pollen, or he said, I'm desensitized to bee stings.
segments.cn: 在最后一个短语中，当吉姆谈论可能对花粉过敏时，或者他说，我对蜜蜂蜇的反应减弱了。

segments.en: Alright, so desensitized, you should know automatically that prefix D means not.
segments.cn: 好吧，减敏，你应该自动知道前缀D意味着不。

segments.en: Mm-hmm.
D means that I'm not sensitive to, alright?
segments.cn: D意味着我对……不敏感，好吗？

segments.en: That means that, you know, if I get stung by a bee, like me, it gets big and red, and it hurts.
segments.cn: 这意味着，如果我被蜜蜂蜇了，就像我一样，会肿胀变红，并且很痛。

segments.en: Right.
But this person, he doesn't have a reaction.
He's desensitized.
So there's no reaction.
There's no red.
There's no swelling.
I think you see it a lot for people that maybe live in an area where there are a lot of mosquitoes.
segments.cn: 我想你经常看到那些可能生活在蚊子很多的地方的人。

segments.en: And if we go there, we're going to get bitten, and it's going to be itchy.
segments.cn: 如果我们去那里，我们会被咬，而且会很痒。

segments.en: But people who live there, they've been bitten so many times that they probably don't even feel it or probably don't even get bitten anymore.
segments.cn: 但住在那里的人，他们被咬了这么多次，可能连感觉都没有，或者可能不再被咬了。

segments.en: They're desensitized.
That's right.
Or you could say that I'm desensitized to loud noises.
segments.cn: 或者你可以说我对大声噪音减敏。

segments.en: Okay, I live in a city, and there's a Metro near my apartment.
segments.cn: 好吧，我住在一个城市，公寓附近有地铁。

segments.en: I can hear it.
It's very loud.
Uh-huh.
And so I'm desensitized to the noise.
That means I don't really notice it anymore.
segments.cn: 这意味着我不再注意它。

segments.en: It doesn't bother me.
Right.
Very good.
So that's all the vocab and phrases we've prepared for you today.
segments.cn: 所以这就是我们今天为你准备的所有词汇和短语。

segments.en: Let's listen to this dialogue one last time.
segments.cn: 让我们最后再听一次这个对话。

segments.en: Oh, I feel terrible.
I keep sneezing, and my eyes are all watery.
segments.cn: 我一直在打喷嚏，眼睛也流泪。

segments.en: What's wrong with me?
Wow, you're not dying, are you?
It looks like you have a cold.
You should take some medicine.
I don't think it's a cold.
I feel fine if I move a few feet away from my desk.
segments.cn: 如果我离桌子几步远，我感觉很好。

segments.en: Maybe we should put you into quarantine.
segments.cn: 也许我们应该把你隔离起来。

segments.en: Jokes aside, I think you might have an allergy.
segments.cn: 开玩笑的，我觉得你可能有过敏。

segments.en: An allergy?
I never thought about that.
I don't think I'm allergic to pollen, though, and I'm desensitized to bee stings after being stung so many times.
segments.cn: 不过我觉得我对花粉过敏，而且被蜜蜂蜇了这么多次，我对蜜蜂蜇的反应已经脱敏了。

segments.en: Hmm.
Ow!
Why did you Chuck that peanut at me?
segments.cn: 你为什么把那个花生扔给我？

segments.en: Just checking if you're allergic to peanuts.
segments.cn: 只是想看看你对花生过敏吗。

segments.en: I guess not.
Not funny.
I could have gone into anaphylactic shock.
segments.cn: 我可能会进入过敏性休克。

segments.en: Okay, my bad.
How about dust?
This office is full of it.
Yes, the whole office is dusty, yet I only feel affected near our desks.
segments.cn: 是的，整个办公室都很脏，但我只在我们的桌子附近感到不适。

segments.en: You brought your cat into the office?
segments.cn: 你把你的猫带到办公室来了？

segments.en: Yeah, it's Mr. Snuffle's birthday today.
segments.cn: 是的，今天是斯纳夫尔先生的生日。

segments.en: I didn't want him to be alone on his special day.
segments.cn: 我不想让他在特别的日子里孤单。

segments.en: Ah, put it away!
I guess we found the problem.
You're allergic to cats.
Alright, so speaking about allergies, we always talk about the common ones, like pollen, dust.
segments.cn: 好吧，谈到过敏，我们总是谈论常见的，比如花粉、灰尘。

segments.en: And you also mentioned about food, like somebody who cannot drink milk.
segments.cn: 你还提到过食物，比如不能喝牛奶的人。

segments.en: They're allergic to milk.
That's right.
We have a special name for this, actually.
segments.cn: 实际上我们有一个特别的名称。

segments.en: Someone who cannot drink milk or dairy products, like ice cream, is called lactose intolerant.
segments.cn: 不能喝牛奶或乳制品（如冰淇淋）的人叫乳糖不耐症。

segments.en: So, if you're lactose intolerant, it means that your stomach is very upset after you have dairy products.
segments.cn: 所以，如果你乳糖不耐症，意味着你在吃乳制品后肚子会很不舒服。

segments.en: Because lactose is basically dairy.
segments.cn: 因为乳糖基本上就是乳制品。

segments.en: And there are some people also who are allergic to seafood.
segments.cn: 还有一些人对海鲜过敏。

segments.en: For example, fish or shrimp or any type of seafood.
segments.cn: 比如鱼、虾或任何类型的海鲜。

segments.en: That's right.
And also people who are allergic to gluten.
segments.cn: 还有一些人对面筋过敏。

segments.en: Now gluten is a very common product that is found in breads and cereal, things like that.
segments.cn: 面筋是一种常见的成分，存在于面包和谷物等食物中。

segments.en: And so people who have an allergy to gluten actually have to change their diet quite a bit.
segments.cn: 所以对面筋过敏的人实际上需要改变他们的饮食。

segments.en: Yeah, they have to look for things that are gluten-free, which is very hard because apparently it's in everything.
segments.cn: 是的，他们必须寻找无面筋的食物，这很难，因为显然它无处不在。

segments.en: That's right.
So if you have one of these allergies, you can find dairy-free on the box or gluten-free on the box.
segments.cn: 所以如果你有这些过敏，你可以在包装上找到无乳制品或无面筋的标签。

segments.en: And specialty food stores will have these labels.
segments.cn: 特殊食品商店会有这些标签。

segments.en: And so are you allergic to anything?
No, not really.
Sometimes here in China, I feel like I'm a little bit allergic.
segments.cn: 有时候在中国，我觉得我有点过敏。

segments.en: I have allergies when the seasons change.
segments.cn: 我在季节变化时会过敏。

segments.en: But at home, no.
I have no allergies.
No allergies.
No, me neither.
And I'm very lucky, I think, because I can't imagine if I had an allergy to peanuts or to seafood.
segments.cn: 我觉得我很幸运，因为我无法想象如果我对花生或海鲜过敏会怎样。

segments.en: Which not only would be a shame because you can't have these foods, but if you accidentally have it, it could be life-threatening.
segments.cn: 这不仅会很可惜，因为你不能吃这些食物，而且如果你不小心吃了，可能会危及生命。

segments.en: That's right.
Like my dad, who is allergic to bees, would go into anaphylactic shock if he were stung.
segments.cn: 就像我爸爸，他对蜜蜂过敏，如果被蜇了会进入过敏性休克。

segments.en: And so you have to be very careful because you never know when you'll have an accident like that.
segments.cn: 所以你必须非常小心，因为你永远不知道什么时候会发生这样的意外。

segments.en: Exactly.
So this is an interesting topic.
Maybe you guys want to share if you are allergic to anything.
segments.cn: 也许你们想分享一下你们是否对什么过敏。

segments.en: Maybe you are allergic to certain types of foods, chemicals.
segments.cn: 也许你对某些类型的食物、化学物质过敏。

segments.en: Some people are allergic to certain types of shampoo, for example.
segments.cn: 有些人对某些类型的洗发水过敏，例如。

segments.en: Or fabrics like cotton.
So if you want to share with us, let us know at our website, EnglishPod.com.
segments.cn: 所以如果你想和我们分享，请在我们的网站 EnglishPod.com 上告诉我们。

segments.en: We'll see you guys there.
Bye.
